title.narrative: Emergency WASH response in IDPs camps and host communities in Dikwa and Ngala LGAs

description.narrative:
The complex emergency and conflict in North East Nigeria started in 2009 and has resulted in the displacement of over 2 million people (DTM Aug 2019). Overall, 7.1 million people are in dire need of assistance across Borno, Adamawa and Yobe (BAY) states (HRP 2019-2021). The situation of IDPs is critical, as they are living in severely congested temporary camps, prone to regular epidemics, rain, flooding and fire incidents. Due to increased hostilities and insecurity, the number of registered displacements continue to increase (by 2% over last 4 months’ period), and is expected to continue, as the Nigerian Government Forces recently adopted the strategy of establishing “super camps” to strengthen their defenses in areas with population concentration, thereby removing troops from remote areas. This strategy will result in further displacements of IDPs, moving to secure locations in August and September 2019 alone, over 26 thousand movements triggered by factors such as conflict, insecurity, fear of attacks, military operations and poor living conditions, were registered (IOM ETT reports (29 July – 22nd Sep).
Due to ongoing conflict and security operation in Borno, 5 Local Government Areas - LGAs (Guzamala, Marte, Kukawa, Abadam and Kala/Balge) are indeed considered completely inaccessible while 8 more LGAs – Bama, Damboa, Dikwa, Gwoza, Konduga, Monguno, Ngala and Nganzai - are considered “hard to reach” or partially accessible3. Among them, Dikwa and Ngala systematically appear in the top 4 of “hard to reach” LGAs with the least access to health services, permanent shelters, safe water and the highest rate of malnutrition and protection issues (REACH - November 2018 - April 2019). Some sites in Dikwa have access to less than 5L/pers/day of safe water. In terms of sanitation, 68% of the sites referenced by the WASH Sector in “hard to reach” LGAs do not comply with the SPHERE standard of 50 pers/functional latrines and 20% of those are in Dikwa and Ngala LGAs. Those 2 LGAs were also part of the 4 “hard to reach” hotspots of 2018 cholera outbreak, making them vital targets for improved WASH services.
SI is thus proposing to intervene in Dikwa and Ngala LGAs under this project through: 1. Rehabilitation, operation and maintenance of water points in the most vulnerable camps as well as the drilling of one shallow water point in one host community in Ngala LGA 2. Construction of emergency blocks of latrines and bathing facilities in vulnerable camps and host communities in both locations 3. Flood mitigation measures as part of cholera prevention 4. Cholera tailored hygiene promotion activities as part of cholera prevention and preparedness
In total, the proposed project is targeting 69,067 individuals.
